ygData.msgSnippet: Hi, Just a couple of thoughts. If you re training on a long period of price data then you should probably inflation adjust the prices, e.g. yahoo finance has

Subject: Re: [neat] Time Series Prediction and NEAT
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=344770313; y=wIsfS5GoKEtrkcSmZnTDzBESqquAqsURHtBJJM_m78PNY994RnHQ

Hi,

Just a couple of thoughts. If you're training on a long period of
price data then you should probably inflation adjust the prices, e.g.
yahoo finance has daily prices for the S&P 500 going back 50 years,
the dow goes back even further. Thus when you calculate price deltas
for each day a delta from 1950 will be in the same units as for the
pesent day (e.g. 2009 dollars). Now because the price delta
distribution has fat tails (more big daily changes than a gaussion
distribution) if you normalize the deltas you will compress the bulk
of daily prices changes into a very small value range, to overcome
this I would consider using Log(delta), and by all means normalize to
[-1,1] after taking the log.

I've not tried the sliding window approach but it sounds viable, it
also sounds like a good candiate for HyperNEAT because (A) there are a
large number of inputs and (B) the existence of a geometric
relationship between the inputs, albeit in time rather than space.

I have a hypothesis that such an approach would generate profitable
strategies for historic data (e.g. train against 1950-60 and test
against 1960-70), but that with the advent of algorithmic and internet
trading market dynamics are conitunally shifting such that an
algorithm that is profitable today may not be profitable tomorrow.
E.g. you may have heard the rumours about Goldman Sachs gaming the
system and being thrown off the NYSE electronic exchange - if true
then the removal of such a large market participant will have altered
market dynamics to some degree.

There is at least one historic pricing anomaly that I'm aware of that
could have been used to make money had you known about it, that being
the mispricing of options using the black-scholes formula from about
the mid 1970's until around the time of the LTCM collapse ('98 I
think). An AI might well pick up on the discrepancy, but for that
you'd need option pricing data which generally costs a lot of money -
and some knowledge of option pricing of course.

Colin
